description: From Spanish contrabanda (modern spelling contrabando), from Italian contrabando (modern spelling contrabbando), from contra (“against”) + bando (“ban”), and reinforced by French contrebande.

adjectives.description: contraband (comparative more contraband, superlative most contraband)

examples: "[...] when the seizure is made in connection with a violation involving a contraband article covered by section 1 (b) (1) of the said Act; [...]"

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Any goods which are illicit or illegal to possess.
(uncountable) Goods which are prohibited from being traded, smuggled goods.
(countable, US, historical) A black slave during the American Civil War who had escaped to, or been captured by, Union forces.
examples: While some Yanks treated contrabands with a degree of equity or benevolence, the more typical response was indifference, contempt, or cruelty.

verbs.description: contraband (third-person singular simple present contrabands, present participle contrabanding, simple past and past participle contrabanded)
